Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This class is excellent for learning about the nuances of the American political system. The readings provide interesting evidence in light of some of the commonly asked questions regarding the American political system (such as "is the American political system broken"?). It is not just an AP Gov class; it goes far more in depth, and the lessons/reading connect to each other in really interesting ways.

I definitely improved my skills and speed in reading very large homework assignments. Over time, I learned about which parts of the readings were essential to read, and which parts could be skimmed or skipped. 
I also gained insight on how the political process functions in the US today, as well as why certain institutions are structured the way they are.
Basic functions of the American political system

This class provided an in depth introduction into American political institutions, political behavior, and political science research. Professor Huber does a good job providing an analytical framework though which to understand American politics.
The main thing I will take away from this class is that we need to be skeptical of polling data. We also focused on what constitutes an informed voter.

This course introduced me to the skill of thinking critically about politics and how the fundamental foundations of our government affect how our country is run today. I loved being introduced to game theory through public and congressional voting models. Professor Huber said that the course wouldn't be a traditional high school American Government course and he definitely delivered.
I learned a lot about how U.S. gov functions
Understanding of how American political systems work and the history that led to the systems we currently have in place.
I learned how to digest large amounts of information- textbook based, and lecture based. I also learned a lot about interpreting the results of political science studies into thematic observations.

I learned a lot about basic political theory, the functions and roles of the president, Congress, the Supreme Court, the bureaucracy, media in politics, etc. I also had a lot of practice reading and dissecting actual political science papers.  As I've gained a greater understanding of the US government, I've noticed a lot of the content appearing in my every day life outside of class.
I developed an understanding of the basic politics of American government, as well as further my knowledge of the structure of the federal system.
Gained a significantly deeper understanding about the origins and structure of the American Political system. Also learned about the behaviors of American constituents.
Introduction to political science and a deeper understanding of American government and political systems
I gained a greater understanding of why the government works the way it does, not just how it works.

I gained a tremendous amount of experience dealing not only with the political science topics proposed in this course, but also how to effectively convey my arguments relating to those issues through writing.
I learned applicable reading and writing skills in the domain of political science. I learned how to meaningfully engage with politics.
The history and current state of the American political system.
I learned about how the American political system functions and how political science works as a study.
A fundamental knowledge of us government.
I learned about the workings of the American political system that I did not know before.
I learned how to think critically and create convincing arguments in argumentative papers
Knowledge about the American political system in depth
The fundamental concepts at the center of modern American government and the history of events that led up to them.
I received skills on how to properly analyze and discuss different events within American politics.
I was introduced to some of the fundamental topics surrounding both historical and contemporary American politics.

How to read quickly
Understanding modern political atmosphere
Understanding how we arrived at our current government apparatuses
So much about the field of poli sci in general
I learned about the structure of government institutions and how they came to be established. I think the course went strategically in a chronological way. I also learned how to create an argument.
I gained a greater insight into how political science research works (especially at Yale) and how the United States government operates.

Professor Huber is an excellent lecturerenthusiastic, knowledgeable, and brilliant. The discussion sections felt less helpful/engaging. That is not a criticism of my TF, who was great. Rather, since I understood most of the lecture/reading material on my own, I did not feel the need to have the material reinforced via discussion.

The course gives a broad overview of the essential aspects of institution structure, political bargaining and policy-making, and the role of different groups of people in politics. The lectures presented and adequate but not excessive amount of information.
I did feel, however, that the assigned readings were sometimes way too big. I felt that I often could not read all the assigned material in depth if I wanted to do the homework in a reasonable amount of time.
strengths is professor huber's way of lecturing, very engaging

Strengths: Professor Huber is a great lecturer. The course readings can be dense but are extremely interesting and the class as a whole is very well organized. 

Weaknesses: the class felt a little bit basic at times and started out somewhat slow.
I would say the strengths of this course is definitely the lectures by Professor Huber. He has a way of explaining complex ideas in a detail-oriented manner.

The strengths of this course really stem from the readings and weekly section meetings. The assigned readings for this course can pile up quickly and be difficult to manage, but the material is beyond a superficial understanding of "what things do" and more of "why do these things happen." Additionally, weekly section meetings brought great energy to discussing the course material and debating different interpretations and implications of course concepts. One thing that should be improved, however, is the ability to clearly comprehend the readings. As an introductory course, many students are taking this class as their first political science course and some of the readings (ex. Tocqueville), especially towards the beginning of the year, are very difficult to wrap one's head around. Moreover, many of these readings are tested on weekly quizzes when students can't even comprehend them in the first place. I'd just suggest some small tweak that allows an easier engagement and comprehension of course readings.
Lectures are very engaging. Pretty easy to do well in if you put in the work.

One thing that Professor Huber emphasized the first couple of classes which I think definitely held true was that this is not just AP US Government. The course focuses more on how the political systems within government work.

Strengths: Fantastic TF's and interesting readings. Prof Huber does a good job explaining how the system of government works.
Weaknesses: Lectures were dry at times, and during reading week, the class was portrayed to be a lot less like U.S. Government in high school than it is. Would still recommend because it is more in depth and focuses on political science studies than U.S. Gov does, but know that this course will mirror that a little.

strengths: manageable workload, engaging lectures
weaknesses: if you don't get a good TF then section is excruciating, would've loved more real-life examples of the concepts we discussed or cases to see the mechanisms we discuss in action

I think that the course did a nice job covering a range of important topics for students beginning to study the US government. It was structured in a way that allowed for a pretty comprehensive understanding of each topic, but I felt that it always moved onto the next topic at the appropriate time to remain engaging. I would say that the readings were for the most part pretty interesting, but I found many of them to be unnecessarily long, almost to the point that I couldn't get through them.
Section assignments varied greatly between TA's. A more structured section system, in the sense that all sections have similar expectations, would make the course seem more fair.
Some of the readings were very technical and had a lot of math/statistics

Strengths - Professor Huber is an incredible lecturer
Weaknesses - the reading check quizzes were challenging, even if you did the readings

Prof. Huber is without a doubt one of the most knowledgeable academics in his field and his lectures provided tremendous insight into the issues that face our nation today as well as their relation to past political events. The TA's for the course, however, were, in my experience, in over their heads in terms of workload. My personal TA seemed almost obligated to be in their position and lacked a sense of commitment.
This class discussed important issues in political both in the past and today. It was a super interesting and relevant course.
Strengths: The course offers a very interesting view of today's politics. Other than learning how government works, you also learn why it works the way it does.
One strength would be the open note exams. One weakness would be the slow discussions in section.

Strength: lectures were very interesting, section was great, and I appreciated the option of final paper vs exam and the open note exams. 
Weakness: I felt like many quiz questions were a bit obscure and I still got questions wrong even after completing all the readings, which was very discouraging.

I felt that the material we were given in this class, especially the textbook, was not always reflected in the examinations. For the midterm exam, I studied more on the structure of the political system rather than the findings of the modern political system. I also felt that the examinations count too much for the overall grade.

Strengths: interesting material, TA provided awesome feedback on both papers
Weaknesses: pop quizzes were not easy even when I read the material, too many readings that werent covered in class

Strengths: touches many aspects of American political system
Weaknesses: the course isnt cohesive
I think the strengths of this course was the level of organization and the way the lectures were planned out. There were no real outstanding weaknesses of this course.

Some of the readings are really interesting. I especially liked how the readings came from all different time periods, some of them were even from America's founding. At times the readings can be dense, with a fair amount of empirical data.

SO much reading - in my opinion, too much. I really wanted to enjoy and absorb the reading but didn't feel like I could because there was so much to get through that I had to rush.

Such an engaging lecturer, clear and concise slides, many different types of learning facilitated (for example, choice between final paper or exam), loved how pertinent the topic was.

Strengths include excellent lecturer and engaging presentation and relevant course readings. Improvements could be relating material to current events happening in government and to provide answers to the practice tests before mid terms. I think it would help us get a better sense of how we are doing on the practice test and make us feel more confident going into the actual test.

This course covers a lot of different material and definitely gives students a good insight into political science research. Its main weakness, I would say, is the weekly quizzes. Oftentimes, it felt that even when students did all the readings, it was still difficult to get a good grade on these quizzes.

I would recommend this course; for anyone interested in American politics, this provides a very solid foundation. Professor Huber is awesome. However, be prepared for a lot of reading; usually, for each class, there is about 40 pages of textbook reading plus 1 or 2 (usually very dense) research articles. And it's hard to skip the readings and do well in the class; there are pop quizzes on the reading, and you have to do a 1-2 page "memo" each week (basically a summary/analysis of the readings). But, overall, it is worth it; I learned a lot about the American political system, and most people I knew seemed to do well as long as they kept up with their work.
Yes, I would recommend this course. It gives us a general framework of how American politics came to be and how they function, as well as what you as a a citizen should be mindful of.
yes if you want a basic understanding of US government, good foundational course and can use the information in other political science courses
Yes if you do not have a strong background in American Politics. Otherwise, I think most of the class material isn't particularly helpful.
Yes. A good way to learn about the US government and dip your toes into the political science waters. Very manageable, reasonable expectations, and good lectures.
Despite the overall workload of the course, I think the topics discussed and the fact you get to learn from Professor Huber make the course worth taking.

I would definitely recommend this course. By the end of the course, you definitely feel like you have a better grasp over American politics and the problems in Washington today. It definitely teaches you how to be a more informed yet skeptical consumer of political information and how to analyze the media carefully. Take this course if you have the chance.
Yes. good.

Would recommend to anyone considering an intro course in political science, or who wants to focus on American politics. At the end of the course, many students in my section agreed that this was a great course for those wondering about political science because even if you're not a major, the workings of government affect everyone's lives.
definitely.

I would recommend this course to someone who wants to gain a base in US government/politics. I had never taken a government or civics class so I found it to be informative, but I can imagine it being repetitive or less exciting for someone who already has a base.

This course resembles AP US Government, but it digresses much more into the politics of the system, and analyzes political science research. I would recommend this course to an individual who is not confident in the American political system, as well as those looking to further their understanding of the political game played between officeholders.

Yes, especially if you are interested in going into politics. I feel that it made me a more conscious voter and that I understand "the system" a bit better. Might not help with the requirements for the Political Science major though.
Yes, it is an excellent introductory course to the political science dept at yale

Yes, this course should be required for all students because it would make us all more informed students, citizens, and voters. Professor Huber's lectures are totally awesome, and the content is interesting.
I would. While the TAs presented a few problems to the course, Prof. Huber's lectures guided by the assigned readings proved quite fascinated and academically useful.
I would strongly recommend this course to another student.  It was educational with a relatively low work load.
Yes, definitely
Absolutely, I learned a lot and I never lost interest in the class throughout the semester.
I think the course is great for providing an understanding on how our political system works, so we can much better participate.
Yes. It provides a great introduction to studying American government and the political science major.
Yes, if you are interested in reading about American govt.
Yes, interesting material and teaches you how to write a convincing argument.
Yes, if youre looking to take an intro class on this topic
I would certainly recommend this course to a fellow student considering political science as a major. This is because I believe this course gave a very good introduction to American politics.
I would recommend this class because I think it offers a strong foundation of American politics and gives a great sense of what the political science department is like.

Yes if you want a background in the workings of politics. I feel so much more motivated to be politically engaged because I can understand the political sphere so much better. This class induced me to sign up for NYT daily memo emails and I am strongly considering taking more poli sci classes.
Yes, I think it is a strong foundational course and a good backbone if a student decides to later take more political science classes.
If you're interested in doing political science research, this is probably a good class for you.
